solution:
We can write
\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{\cos^2 10^\circ} &= \frac{2}{1 + \cos 20^\circ} \\
&= \frac{2 (1 - \cos 20^\circ)}{(1 + \cos 20^\circ)(1 - \cos 20^\circ)} \\
&= \frac{2 (1 - \cos 20^\circ)}{1 - \cos^2 20^\circ} \\
&= \frac{2 - 2 \cos 20^\circ}{\sin^2 20^\circ},
\end{align*}so
\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{\cos^2 10^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 20^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 40^\circ} &= \frac{2 - 2 \cos 20^\circ}{\sin^2 20^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 20^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 40^\circ} \\
&= \frac{3 - 2 \cos 20^\circ}{\sin^2 20^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 40^\circ} \\
&= \frac{4 \cos^2 20^\circ (3 - 2 \cos 20^\circ)}{4 \sin^2 20^\circ \cos^2 20^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 40^\circ} \\
&= \frac{12 \cos^2 20^\circ - 8 \cos^3 20^\circ}{\sin^2 40^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 40^\circ} \\
&= \frac{12 \cos^2 20^\circ - 8 \cos^3 20^\circ + 1}{\sin^2 40^\circ}.
\end{align*}By the triple angle formula,
\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{2} &= \cos 60^\circ \\
&= \cos (3 \cdot 20^\circ) \\
&= 4 \cos^3 20^\circ - 3 \cos 20^\circ,
\end{align*}which means $8 \cos^3 20^\circ = 6 \cos 20^\circ + 1.$  Hence,
\begin{align*}
\frac{12 \cos^2 20^\circ - 8 \cos^3 20^\circ + 1}{\sin^2 40^\circ} &= \frac{12 \cos^2 20^\circ - 6 \cos 20^\circ}{\sin^2 40^\circ} \\
&= \frac{12 \cos^2 20^\circ - 6 \cos 20^\circ}{4 \sin^2 20^\circ \cos^2 20^\circ} \\
&= \frac{12 \cos 20^\circ - 6}{4 \sin^2 20^\circ \cos 20^\circ} \\
&= \frac{12 \cos 20^\circ - 6}{4 (1 - \cos^2 20^\circ) \cos 20^\circ} \\
&= \frac{12 \cos 20^\circ - 6}{4 \cos 20^\circ - 4 \cos^3 20^\circ} \\
&= \frac{12 \cos 20^\circ - 6}{4 \cos 20^\circ - 3 \cos 20^\circ - \frac{1}{2}} \\
&= \frac{12 \cos 20^\circ - 6}{\cos 20^\circ - \frac{1}{2}} \\
&= \boxed{12}.
\end{align*}
model_solution:
Step 1: Apply the Pythagorean identities to rewrite the expression in terms of trigonometric functions of 10°, 20°, and 40°:
\[\frac{1}{\cos^2 10^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 20^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 40^\circ} = \frac{1}{(1 - \sin^2 10^\circ)} + \frac{1}{(1 - \cos^2 20^\circ)} + \frac{1}{(1 - \cos^2 40^\circ)}.\]
Step 2: Use the identity \(\sin (90^\circ - \theta) = \cos \theta\) to simplify the denominators of the expression: 
\[\frac{1}{(1 - \sin^2 10^\circ)} + \frac{1}{(1 - \cos^2 20^\circ)} + \frac{1}{(1 - \cos^2 40^\circ)} = \frac{1}{\cos^2 80^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 70^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 50^\circ}.\]
Step 3: Apply the Pythagorean identities to rewrite each of the denominators in the first two terms and the third term:
\[\frac{1}{\cos^2 80^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 70^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 50^\circ} = \frac{1}{1 - \sin^2 80^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 70^\circ} + \frac{1}{1 - \cos^2 50^\circ}.\]
Step 4:
\[\frac{1}{1 - \sin^2 80^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 70^\circ} + \frac{1}{1 - \cos^2 50^\circ} = \frac{1}{\cos^2 10^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 70^\circ} + \frac{1}{\cos^2 40^\circ}.\]
\[\frac{1}{\cos^2 10^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 70^\circ} + \frac{1}{\cos^2 40^\circ} = \frac{1}{\cos^2 10^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin (90^\circ - 20^\circ)^2} + \frac{1}{\cos^2 40^\circ}.\]
\[\frac{1}{\cos^2 10^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin (90^\circ - 20^\circ)^2} + \frac{1}{\cos^2 40^\circ} = \frac{1}{\cos^2 10^\circ} + \frac{1}{\cos^2 20^\circ} + \frac{1}{\cos^2 40^\circ}.\]
\[\frac{1}{\cos^2 10^\circ} + \frac{1}{\cos^2 20^\circ} + \frac{1}{\cos^2 40^\circ} = \frac{1}{\cos^2 10^\circ} + \frac{\cos^2 20^\circ}{\cos^2 20^\circ} + \frac{\cos^2 40^\circ}{\cos^2 40^\circ}.\]
\[\frac{1}{\cos^2 10^\circ} + \frac{\cos^2 20^\circ}{\cos^2 20^\circ} + \frac{\cos^2 40^\circ}{\cos^2 40^\circ} = \frac{1}{\cos^2 10^\circ} + 1 + 1.\]
\[\frac{1}{\cos^2 10^\circ} + 1 + 1 = \frac{1}{\cos^2 10^\circ} + 2\]
\[\frac{1}{\cos^2 10^\circ} + 2 = \frac{1}{\cos^2 10^\circ} + \frac{\cos^2 10^\circ}{\cos^2 10^\circ}.\]
steps:
Step 1: Apply the Pythagorean identities to rewrite the expression in terms of trigonometric functions of 10°, 20°, and 40°:
\[\frac{1}{\cos^2 10^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 20^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 40^\circ} = \frac{1}{(1 - \sin^2 10^\circ)} + \frac{1}{(1 - \cos^2 20^\circ)} + \frac{1}{(1 - \cos^2 40^\circ)}.\]

Step 2: Use the identity \(\sin (90^\circ - \theta) = \cos \theta\) to simplify the denominators of the expression: 
\[\frac{1}{(1 - \sin^2 10^\circ)} + \frac{1}{(1 - \cos^2 20^\circ)} + \frac{1}{(1 - \cos^2 40^\circ)} = \frac{1}{\cos^2 80^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 70^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 50^\circ}.\]

Step 3: Apply the Pythagorean identities to rewrite each of the denominators in the first two terms and the third term:
\[\frac{1}{\cos^2 80^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 70^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 50^\circ} = \frac{1}{1 - \sin^2 80^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 70^\circ} + \frac{1}{1 - \cos^2 50^\circ}.\]
full_steps:
Step 1: Apply the Pythagorean identities to rewrite the expression in terms of trigonometric functions of 10°, 20°, and 40°:
\[\frac{1}{\cos^2 10^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 20^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 40^\circ} = \frac{1}{(1 - \sin^2 10^\circ)} + \frac{1}{(1 - \cos^2 20^\circ)} + \frac{1}{(1 - \cos^2 40^\circ)}.\]

Step 2: Use the identity \(\sin (90^\circ - \theta) = \cos \theta\) to simplify the denominators of the expression: 
\[\frac{1}{(1 - \sin^2 10^\circ)} + \frac{1}{(1 - \cos^2 20^\circ)} + \frac{1}{(1 - \cos^2 40^\circ)} = \frac{1}{\cos^2 80^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 70^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 50^\circ}.\]

Step 3: Apply the Pythagorean identities to rewrite each of the denominators in the first two terms and the third term:
\[\frac{1}{\cos^2 80^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 70^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 50^\circ} = \frac{1}{1 - \sin^2 80^\circ} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 70^\circ} + \frac{1}{1 - \cos^2 50^\circ}.\]
